title: Carers blew Parkinson’s patient’s life savings on make-up and new clothes
text:
Leanne Reynolds and Louise Pritchard-Stapleton abused their positions to pilfer money from a vulnerable resident (Picture: Liverpool Echo)

Two carers helped themselves to the life savings of a pensioner with Parkinson’s, blowing thousands on new clothes and cosmetics.

Sandra Smith, 70, suffered from epilepsy and required around-the-clock care at St George’s Care Home in Wallasey.

Louise Pritchard-Stapleton and Leanne Reynolds were two of those who were meant to be looking after her.

But instead they hijacked Mrs Smith’s bank details and began pilfering cash ‘drip by drip’ – eventually blowing almost £6,500 of the frail resident’s £9,000 pot.

Liverpool Crown Court heard Pritchard-Stapleton spent almost £5,000 treating herself to fake eyelashes, hair extensions and new outfits while Reynolds spent almost £1,500 on Amazon buying gifts for her children.

Pritchard-Stapleton was jailed for nine months and Reynolds was handed a six-month suspended sentence after they both admitted fraud.

Louise Pritchard-Stapleton was jailed for nine months (Picture: Liverpool Echo)

Her brother Jonathon Pritchard admitted money laundering but was spared jail (Picture: Liverpool Echo)

The court heard Pritchard-Stapleton told Mrs Smith £1,100 had been paid into a Just Giving account raising money for a specialist wheelchair for a sick 15-year-old girl whose leg had been amputated.

But prosecutor Jonathan Rogers said: ‘That was a load of rubbish. It was set up as part of this fraud to take money from the victim.’

Her brother, bodybuilder Jonathan Pritchard, admitted money laundering after some of the funds were moved into his bank account and spent within a fortnight.

He was given a 12-month community order and ordered to carry out 200 hours’ unpaid work.

Pritchard-Stapleton only worked at the home for four weeks in 2017, but kept stealing money over 12 months.

The offences came to light when someone tipped off the home that she had the victim’s bank details.

Of the 228 purchases she made using the pensioner’s details, £1,500 went on paying her phone bill.

Reynolds worked at the home for three months in 2017 and 2018, before going on maternity leave.

She suggested she bought Mrs Smith items on Amazon, then accidentally used her details for herself, the Liverpool Echo reported.

The victim said: ‘This was very distressing for me and I was upset with myself for not keeping a closer eye on my own finances.’

Supporters of Pritchard-Stapleton swore at the judge after she was sent down (Picture: Liverpool Echo)

Leanne Reynolds also admitted fraud after spending hundreds on Amazon (Picture: Liverpool Echo)

Judge David Aubrey QC said they were ’mean, despicable offences’ and the victim’s life savings were ‘pilfered and purloined’.

He said she was ‘particularly vulnerable’, but while she lay in bed ill, Pritchard-Stapleton stole her money ‘drip by drip’.

Supporters of Pritchard-Stapleton and her brother swore at the judge as she was sent down.

description: Louise Pritchard-Stapleton and Leanne Reynolds abused their positions to pilfer money from Sandra Smith, who suffers with Parkinson's.
